channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Egypt’s President Replaces Intelligence Chief
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi removed Gen. Mohamed Farid el-Tohamy, an influential mentor, and named Khaled Fawzy, a top deputy in the intelligence service, as his successor.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Chinese Annoyance With North Korea Bubbles to the Surface
item.description: A retired general’s scathing account of North Korea as a recalcitrant ally headed for collapse and unworthy of China’s support revealed how far relations between the two countries have sunk.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, right, and Vice President Li Yuanchao of China in Pyongyang in July 2013, the last time a Chinese leader visited.

item.title: Fuel Rods Are Removed From Damaged Fukushima Reactor
item.description: Tokyo Electric Power Company passed one milestone, but faces the far more challenging task of removing the ruined fuel cores from the three reactors that melted down.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Delivery of Helicopters Shows Mending of U.S.-Egypt Ties
item.description: The Americans had imposed a hold on the Apache helicopters last year after the Egyptian military toppled President Mohamed Morsi.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: In a Year, Egypt Detained 10,000
item.description: An aide to the interior minister gave a rare accounting of a crackdown in which those suspected of being militants and rioters were arrested over the past 12 months.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Cuban Exiles at Miami Rally Denounce Obama for Rapprochement
item.description: Hundreds of protesters in Miami excoriated the president for moving to normalize relations with Cuba, which they say will only shore up the Communist regime’s power.
item.dc:creator: By NICK MADIGAN
item.media:description: Evelio Ordonez, 69, at a demonstration in Miami on Saturday against President Obama's decision to normalize relations with the Cuban government.

item.title: Algeria, Dependent on Oil, Feels Pinch as Prices Decline
item.description: Like Russia, which has seen a full-scale run on its currency, Algeria has made little effort to diversify the economy away from oil and gas.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Wake of Hong Kong, Chinese Leader Warns Macau
item.description: In the wake of prolonged pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong, President Xi Jinping raised a warning about interference from external forces.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Gulf States and Qatar Gloss Over Differences, but Split Still Hampers Them
item.description: The lack of unity is raising questions about the ability of the gulf states to muster a coherent response to a storm of crises.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A meeting of the Gulf Cooperation Council in Doha, Qatar, this month produced a communiqué that expressed “full support” for Egypt, an area of dispute.

item.title: In Real Life, ‘Rambo’ Ends Up as a Soldier of Misfortune, Behind Bars
item.description: In a plot that seems lifted from an international thriller, a former Army sniper who became entangled with an arms dealer now stands accused of taking a job as a hired killer.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ALAN FEUER
item.media:description: Joseph Hunter, nicknamed Rambo, was led by Thai police officers after his arrest last year. He is facing life in prison.

item.title: Raúl Castro Thanks U.S., but Reaffirms Communist Rule in Cuba
item.description: In a speech on Saturday, President Raúl Castro thanked President Obama for “a new chapter” while also reaffirming that restored relations did not mean the end of Communist rule in Cuba.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men watched at a barbershop in Havana as President Raúl Castro thanked President Obama for “a new chapter.”

item.title: For Cubans in Miami, the Gulf to Their Homeland Narrows
item.description: The re-establishment of U.S. diplomatic ties with Cuba brought widely different reactions in Miami, where first-generation exiles who remember Fidel Castro’s brutality mix with millennials for whom Cuba is more a cultural touchstone.
item.dc:creator: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ
item.media:credit: Photographs by Ángel Franco/The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Isabel De Lara arrived in Miami in 1961 among the first wave of Cuban refugees; Jose Antonio Lorenzo came during the Mariel boatlift in 1980; Alicia Garcia survived a perilous voyage by raft in 1994; Elsa Riverón, who came in 2011, is part of a newer generation of arrivals.

item.title: Few Liberians Turn Out for Vote Delayed by Ebola
item.description: Extra cardboard dividers and ballot boxes were added at polling places to minimize the risk of voters contracting Ebola, which is spread through physical contact.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIR MacDOUGALL
item.media:description: A Liberian woman cast her vote Saturday in Monrovia as health workers monitored polling stations across Liberia.

item.title: China Invests in Region Rich in Oil, Coal and Also Strife
item.description: China is turning the Xinjiang region into a national hub for oil, gas and coal as Uighurs struggle, resenting the reaping of their homeland’s resources.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Technicians worked in September to repair an oil pump at an oil field on the outskirts of Karamay, China, in the resource-rich Xinjiang region.

item.title: If Not David to the U.S. Goliath, Cuba Asks What Its Role Is Now
item.description: As Cubans absorb the news that the United States will begin normalizing relations with their government after more than five decades of hostility, they are contending with a rush of both excitement and uncertainty.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE and VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: A street in Havana on Friday. For many in Cuba, socialism and the revolution have come to mean two things: free health care and a strong public education system.

item.title: U.S. Asks China to Help Rein In Korean Hackers
item.description: As part of its response to the cyberattack on Sony Pictures, the Obama administration has asked China to assist in blocking North Korea’s ability to launch such attacks.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER, NICOLE PERLROTH and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Workers removing a banner for “The Interview” from a billboard in Hollywood after Sony canceled the movie’s release.

item.title: Six Militants Killed in U.S. Drone Attacks in Pakistan
item.description: The first strike since Taliban fighters killed 148 people, mostly schoolchildren, in a brutal attack on a military-run public school.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Russia Denounces New Round of Western Sanctions
item.description: Russia on Saturday derided the United States, Canada and Europe for another set of economic sanctions and new sanctions aimed at blocking foreign investment in Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on-screen in Crimea in October. The Russian economy has recently gone into a tailspin.

item.title: North Korea Warns U.S. Not to Take Sony Action
item.description: Warning of “serious consequences” if the United States retaliates against it, North Korea on Saturday proposed a joint investigation with Washington to prove that it was not behind the cyberattack on Sony Pictures.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: India Tires of Diplomatic Rift Over Arrest of Devyani Khobragade
item.description: Ms. Khobragade is no longer celebrated in India as a symbol of offended dignity after being arrested by United States marshals in connection with her treatment of her maid.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Devyani Khobragade was arrested a year ago by United States marshals in New York.
